commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Id88b2b77ae225a88238331ca245a0fc90a742039
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-plugin-amqp1 refs/changes/71/572871/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: If3aad2663d76fce58430d3b6ee6220ff550977a3
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
K8s datasource configuration doc

 this document describes how to config kubernetes datasource:

   * copy kubernetes cluster config file
   * copy keys to establish SSL connection
   * config vitrage.conf

Change-Id: I146cf9811cedffb2e4fed6ee96937e6c53e44588
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/vitrage refs/changes/77/571977/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ===================== Kubernetes datesource ===================== This document describes how to configure kubernetes datasource properly. Datasource configuration -------------------------------------- Step 1: _______ In order to access k8s cluster the beneath files should be copied from k8s master and stored where vitrage is installed: * kubeconfig - kubernetes cluster config file is called kubeconfig. * certificate-authority (ca.pem) * client-certificate (kubectl.pem) * client-key (kubectl-key.pem) Kubeconfig example :: apiVersion: v1 kind: Config clusters: - cluster: certificate-authority: /home/k8s/ca.pem server: https://<IP>:<Port> name: bcmt-kubernetes contexts: - context: cluster: bcmt-kubernetes namespace: kube-system user: kubelet name: kubelet-context current-context: kubelet-context preferences: {} users: - name: kubelet user: client-certificate: /home/k8s/kubectl.pem client-key: /home/k8s/kubectl-key.pem keys location (.pem) usually at ``/etc/kubernetes/ssl`` kubeconfig usually location at ``$HOME/.kube/config`` make sure to place the files in the same path as written in kubeconfig file. for example ``ca.pem`` at ``/home/k8s/ca.pem`` Better option is to create a new user + corresponding SSL keys this requires understanding kubernetes (config new user credentials and rules), creating new SSL keys and might be more complicated than the first approach. Step 2: _______ In ``/etc/vitrage/vitrage.conf``: Set the location for kubeconfig file: [kubernetes] config_file = /home/k8s/kubeconfig Add kubernetes to the list of active datasources: [datasources] types = kubernetes

commit_message:
Runtime implementation for non-image type function.

Using 'cgroup' in runtime server to limit cpu and memory resources.

Each pod in deployment will has respective 'cgroup' directory on host.
Under '/sys/fs/cgroup/xx/kubepods/<qos_class>/pod<uid>' directory, use
HOSTNAME to create a new cgroup folder, which will only be used to
limit function execution. Then we do not need to care about how and
when to delete this new folder on host.

Use 'openstackqinling/python-runtime:0.0.3' as the new python runtime
image.

Story: 2001586
Task: 14415
Change-Id: Id04a72c4f4a3c559dc7c746688b13ef93656d125

added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env bash # This is expected to run as root. # Use env HOSTNAME to create cgroup directory, which should only belong to root:root. mkdir /qinling_cgroup/memory/$HOSTNAME mkdir /qinling_cgroup/cpu/$HOSTNAME uwsgi --http :9090 --uid qinling --wsgi-file server.py --callable app --master --processes 5 --threads 1 & uwsgi --http :9092 --uid root --wsgi-file cglimit.py --callable app --master --processes 1 --threads 1

commit_message:
devstack: use cgroupfs driver for both docker and k8s on Cent OS

This is required for resource limiting for non-image functions as we use
the cgroup paths setup by the cgroupfs driver.

Change-Id: I91c50d5ee70a5973f720fd13c6c6214c7361fb7a

commit_message:
Allow Kolla Ceph to deploy bluestore OSDs in Kolla

Support Kolla Ceph to deploy blustore OSDs. With the patch, Kolla
Ceph can deploy bluestore OSDs on ONE, TWO or THREE storage
devices.

Before deploy bluestore OSD, please prepare devices. The detailed
Please refer to [1] for devices initialization.

extend_start.sh: initialize and start bluestore OSD

find_disk.py: search the devices for bluestore OSD

[1]: specs/kolla-ceph-bluestore.rst

Partially-Implements: blueprint kolla-ceph-bluestore

Change-Id: I832f490de63e1aeb68814697cda610a51b622c1f
Signed-off-by: Tone Zhang <tone.zhang@arm.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/10/566810/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: kwargs['partition_label'] = namedef extract_disk_info_bs(ct, dev, name, use_udev): if not dev: return kwargs = dict() kwargs['fs_uuid'] = get_id_fs_uuid(dev, use_udev) kwargs['fs_label'] = dev.get('ID_FS_LABEL', '') kwargs['bs_db_partition'] = '' kwargs['bs_db_label'] = '' kwargs['bs_db_device'] = '' kwargs['bs_wal_partition'] = '' kwargs['bs_wal_label'] = '' kwargs['bs_wal_device'] = '' kwargs['device'] = '' kwargs['partition'] = '' kwargs['partition_label'] = '' kwargs['partition_num'] = '' kwargs['external_journal'] = False kwargs['journal'] = '' kwargs['journal_device'] = '' kwargs['journal_num'] = 0 kwargs['partition_usage'] = 0 if dev.get('DEVTYPE', '') == 'partition': if 'BOOTSTRAP_BS' in name or 'BSDATA' in name: if name == get_id_part_entry_name(dev, use_udev): if '_BS_D' in name: kwargs['partition_usage'] = 'block.db' kwargs['bs_db_device'] = dev.device_node[:-1] kwargs['bs_db_label'] = name elif '_BS_W' in name: kwargs['partition_usage'] = 'block.wal' kwargs['bs_wal_device'] = dev.device_node[:-1] kwargs['bs_wal_label'] = name elif '_BS' in name: kwargs['partition_usage'] = 'block' kwargs['partition'] = dev.device_node[:-1] kwargs['partition_label'] = name kwargs['partition_num'] = \ re.sub(r'.*[^\d]', '', dev.device_node) kwargs['device'] = dev.device_node[:-1] yield kwargs def combine_info(disks): info = list() final = dict() idx=0 idx_osd = idx_wal = idx_db = -1 for item in disks: if item['partition_usage'] == 'block': idx_osd = idx elif item['partition_usage'] == 'block.wal': idx_wal = idx elif item['partition_usage'] == 'block.db': idx_db = idx idx = idx + 1 # write the information of block.db and block.wal to block item # if block.db and block.wal are found if idx_wal != -1: disks[idx_osd]['bs_wal_device'] = disks[idx_wal]['bs_wal_device'] disks[idx_osd]['bs_wal_label'] = disks[idx_wal]['bs_wal_label'] if idx_db != -1: disks[idx_osd]['bs_db_device'] = disks[idx_db]['bs_db_device'] disks[idx_osd]['bs_db_label'] = disks[idx_db]['bs_db_label'] final['fs_uuid'] = disks[idx_osd]['fs_uuid'] final['fs_label'] = disks[idx_osd]['fs_label'] final['bs_db_device'] = disks[idx_osd]['bs_db_device'] final['bs_db_label'] = disks[idx_osd]['bs_db_label'] final['bs_wal_device'] = disks[idx_osd]['bs_wal_device'] final['bs_wal_label'] = disks[idx_osd]['bs_wal_label'] final['device'] = disk[idx_osd]['device'] final['partition'] = disks[idx_osd]['partition'] final['partition_label'] = disks[idx_osd]['partition_label'] final['partition_num'] = disks[idx_osd]['partition_num'] final['external_journal'] = False final['journal'] = '' final['journal_device'] = '' final['journal_num'] = 0 info.append(final) return info if '_BSDATA' in name: for info in extract_disk_info_bs(ct, dev, name, use_udev): if info: ret.append(info) elif '_BS' in name: for info in extract_disk_info_bs(ct, dev, name, use_udev): if info: ret.append(info) for info in extract_disk_info_bs(ct, dev, \ name.replace('_BS', '_BS_W'), use_udev): if info: ret.append(info) for info in extract_disk_info_bs(ct, dev, \ name.replace('_BS', '_BS_D'), use_udev): if info: ret.append(info) else: for info in extract_disk_info(ct, dev, name, use_udev): if info: ret.append(info) if '_BS' in name and len(ret)>0: ret = combine_info(ret)
deleted_lines: for info in extract_disk_info(ct, dev, name, use_udev): if info: ret.append(info)
